description.text:
Remember the 1983 movie Wargames? Seattle teenage hacker David Lightman (played by Matthew Broderick) was trying to impress attractive classmate Jennifer Mack (played by Ally Sheedy), and they accidentally hack into a NORAD missile base and almost start World War 3. A classic rom-com romp.

Well, as we all know the real star of that movie was David's impressive IMSAI based desktop system - 8080 computer with FDC-2 disk drives and the 212A modem and keyboard, all running on a Electrohome 17" monitor - with speech synthesis no less. My first movie crush.

Relive those nostalgic moments of young love/global thermonuclear war with this mini machine set! Mini 3D models of Matthew Broderick and Ally Sheedy sadly not included.

Too lazy to print your own? Buy form our store at http://store.rabbitengineering.com

No real need for instructions - have a close look at the photos and build to match. Note that you'll need to print multiple copies of certain parts (the IMSAI machine bodies, the 8080 switches, the monitor carry handles, etc). The decals are all in stickers.PDF - if you print onto US legal sized paper you'll get the correct scale.

comments.text: Shall we play a game?
comments.author: realmnm

comments.text: You're making me feel old.  When I was looking for my first full-time job (in 1976) one of the places I applied was MITS -- the company that made the IMSAI 8080.  During the interview, I saw one "in the flesh" for the first time.  (Unfortunately I didn't get the job.)  BTW, when it first hit the market, they figured it would be a success if they sold 50 in the first year:  they sold more than 500 in the first two months.
comments.author: ArizonaClark

comments.text: ...as if being old is a bad thing ;-) Great story!
comments.author: ArizonaClark

title: Miniature Queen Anne Sofa Tables
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A collection of 1:24 sofa tables to match the rest of the parlor set.  Two sizes, with a demi lune thrown in for good measure.  Two styles, one exemplifying typical Queen Anne S-curves, and another with faux drawers.  These are scale reproductions of furniture with 36"x12" and 48"x18" footprints.
Building a Makerbot Playset?  Scale the tables up by a factor of 1.5 to get them into 1:18 scale.
Pick your favorite and print upside down without a raft.

comments.text: Very cool. Thanks for posting.
comments.author: GuardToad

comments.text: I love these tables! I came back to grab a model for the nth time and thought I'd let you know this is one of my most common demo items I print to show people what awesome detail my ToM can output. Thanks for the great models!

title: 3D printing for Charity- Angry Birds Piggy Bank

description.text: XYZ Workshop recently printed this wonderful Angry Birds inspired piggy bank in support of a much worthy charity, the Very Special Kids Charity. We are helping our good friend Nat raise funds for this very special charity, Ã¢ÂÂThe Very Special KidsÃ¢ÂÂ Piggy bank appeal. Watch their family story at: http://youtu.be/BYlFqyYdr3U NatÃ¢ÂÂs son, Archie was born with a rare genetic condition and was diagnosed with inoperable tumor when he was just five years old. Sadly for parents Carley and Nathanael Preston, Archie was unwell from the day he was born. But it was the second diagnosis a number of years later that further added to the familyÃ¢ÂÂs already challenging circumstances. Cleo is ArchieÃ¢ÂÂs little sister and unlike most young girls, Cleo worries about her brother going to heaven. She is helping raise money for Very Special Kids in this CleoÃ¢ÂÂs Campaign The PrestonÃ¢ÂÂs and many other families in similar difficult situations get much needed help from the Very Special Kids program, who lighten the load by providing access to respite care at their unique facility. Please help support this program by giving a donation on the official Piggy Bank appeal website - http://www.vsk.org.au/piggybankappeal/cleos-campaign If you like our designs please follow us at http://www.facebook.com/xyzworkshop
The Plug was printed with flexible PLA.

description.text:
The Z-Axis Bed weights work really well. This mod reduces vibrations when on sharp corners and helps eliminates rippling by basically making the bed a much more sturdy build platform.

I made a few changed to retromoonfarmers design:

  1. got rid of the need for a majority of supports during printing it
  2. made the mounting hooks a bit more robust
  3. reduced its wall size to add clearance to the back of the printer
  4. made clearance for the Z axis home sensor.

description.text:
Pocket clip for KangerTech Evod e-cigarette - mine falls out of my shirt pocket when I lean forward - this solves the issue!

The cat was a nice backdrop - I am not advocating that cats should take up smoking :).

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

prusa i3 clone (A8-B anet.com board, gearbest cheapie)

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Printed it vertical.

I printed mine in PLA at 0.2mm layers with 100% fill, which produced a very snug fit part with a stiff clip.
I guess less fill would give more flexibility.

This thing based on the clip highlighted as the source, and was adjusted significantly with Tinkercad.
Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/hBNFK24TqG4

The Kangertech Evod is 15mm diameter;
First I increased the size of the clip to accommodate the larger diameter, such that the internal hole was ~13mm.
Then i created a cylinder as a hole @15mm dia, and applied this to leave a small amount of material at the top to stop the clip from sliding down the evod.
The remaining material at the top was then adjusted by application of a 'hole' cone to create a small champher.
I increased the length of the material holding the body to reach the slots in the chamber of the evod, and added to knobbles on the inside which clip into the slots. I also reduced the clip length.

The clip could be 5mm shorter for easier filling and the champher a little larger to positively engage with the top of the evod better, but it works very well.

This was my first Tinkercad modification, and the source was an STL file, so the resulting design is very much a 'cut and shut' job (have fun if you un-group in tinkercad!!!). Not all the positioning is absolutely perfect.

One interesting observation was that when I loaded the output STL the first time and observed the layers, I found that the body and the clip had a gap between them! So there is a late added rectangle of material overlapping the two parts to ensure that they are one part - you can see the evidence of this in the final print at the join because I left about 0.5mm of the gap present in the final part. I think it adds to the aesthetic.

print_settings.Printer:: CTC black plywood model dual extruder

description.text:
Hello fellow makers,
Printers Unite is here with an original piece of work. A Groot lamp!
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCIdU7UtkdshhI-B_kbkOrYQ
Check out my YouTube Channel for updates :)^

*the model with no right arm is the mark I and was to have another plan to it but I kept the photo because it looks nice :)

Printer:

CTC black plywood model dual extruder

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Print at slowest speeds for a great print for the Groot model.
The box, rails and door don't really matter

A little problem

The only problem I came across was there was a little problem at the jaw part but it's fine because it gives him a little character.

**The problem was the mark I version. The Mark II (Groot_Combined) has support under the chin.

A little inspiration goes a long way

As the title says, I got this idea about 5 months ago but only just started to model and print it because I thought it could never work until the GCC 3d printing competition came along and now I'm rushing to get it done for the competition.

author: winks

description.text:
This is an unofficial PDF guide to operating and using Villamany's excellent 3dpBurner laser cutter/engraver (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:610934). I've published this as a way to help others starting his project get an understanding of some of the concepts and abilities of the device - please be sure to checkout Villamany's website http://3dpburner.blogspot.com and upgrade to 3dpBurner 2!

I'm certainly no expert at this machine or laser cutting/engraving - and my techniques may or may not be the best or easiest way to accomplish things - so please feel free to let everyone know if there's a better way. It did take me quite a while to research and produce this manual, so I do hope it helps.

Use at your own risk - I take no responsibility for missing eyes or damage to your equipment - this is a guide only, and accuracy is not guaranteed. I originally made this to assist other users of my machine (and to jog my own memory...).

I'd also suggest if you have some settings for certain cutting or engraving of items, please post them in the comment for everyone to share! Good luck and have fun!

*
The guide does reference both paid and free programs - ensure you purchase these and support their development.

Great, it works perfectly fine for now thankfully though but look forward to an update in the future!
Perhaps a suggestion to consider if it's not too hard to implement - a visual display as to where the zero is set on the workplane? (eg rectangle showing bed with an "+" or similar on middle etc. That's the main thing I sometimes have problems with - forgetting that I've zeroed elsewhere and then pressing a shortcut location (which are also really great, thanks).

I wanted to make a simple, small dual-E3D mount for the Rigidbot. I used two E3D Lite6s which have been working flawlessly for me. They're spaced 24mm apart, but it took a little bit of tweaking to get it spot-on for me. I haven't had an issue with nozzle height. I used LM8LUU bearings in the slots, but it can also be used with the 3 LM8UU bearings that come with the Rigidbot.

The E3Ds are friction-fit into the holes, and they sit very firmly. The linear bearings are simply snapped into place. The single fan seemed to be sufficient to cool both hotends. Screw it into place like you would with the injection molded clip.

title: Miniature Queen Anne Chaise Lounge
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A 1:24 scale Chaise for lounging, to match the rest of the parlor set.  
*This is a Thing in Progress:  I edited the leg fitting since printing this the first time.  I don't expect any issues, but I haven't actually printed the update myself yet.
Building a Makerbot Playset?  Scale the chaise up by a factor of 1.5 to get it into 1:18 scale.

Print on side as formatted.  A small support rectangle will need to be trimmed of the back with an exacto knife. 
Print from assembled print plate, without a raft.  Or, print body and legs separately.  Body should be printed without a raft.  Four legs are required, and should be printed with a raft.  Use the multiply option in skeinforge to print 4 at once.
Add a drop or three of acetone into the holes, and pop the legs into place.
This thing can be printed with the bottom placed on the build platform, but the angle at the back rest is a little over 45 degrees and loops tend to drop.  The slicing lines are also more attractive when printed on its side.

comments.text: Since its on 1:24 scale, if I wanted to printed for 1:12 scale, I need to reaize it to 200% is that correct?
comments.author: maxwell_hadrian

comments.text: Yes, resize to 200% to convert to 1:12 scale.
comments.author: maxwell_hadrian

comments.text: Printed this in PLA on my Rep2 (10%/2 shells/.20mm) and the legs won't separate from the included, printable plate.  Also, they seem to be too big for the holes.  Suggestions?
comments.author: ukcat

comments.text: I cut them off with an exacto knife, along the layer lines.  They are definitely a tight fit, but should pop in.  I originally designed these for a thingomatic - haven't printed them on my rep 2, but the 2's tolerances should leave more room, not less.
comments.author: ukcat

comments.text: I love what you are doing!!  The one question I've been having is how to scale your 1:24 down to 1:48 for my ¼" models.  I am a theatre set designer too and use ¼" scale most often.  Is there a simple way to do that?  Again, thank you for all that you make available.  I just recently purchased the Replicator2 and love it!!  I am not fond of the makerbot digitizer - it doesn't seem to scan very accurately.
comments.author: mriha

comments.text: I have some quarter scale files I could make available - most of the half inch don't work well when scaled down.  Just need to get around to it...  You need the right conditions to make the digitizer work right: no shine surfaces, the right positions for multi scan - it definitely has a learning curve.  And not everything will scan well, on the digitizer or otherwise.

remixed_from.title: DJI Phantom 3 & Inspire 1 Range Extender – Version E

remixed_from.author: mswarden
remixed_from.title: DJI Phantom 3 & Inspire 1 Range Extender – Version D

title: DJI Phantom 3 Signal/Range Booster Extended Mounts

description.text:
UPDATE: I was able to achieve a new personal distance record of 11,758 feet with the signal booster + these extended mounts.

I love mswarden's DJI Phantom 3 & Inspire 1 Range Extender . His design is accurate, and the antenna is placed at the exact focus of the parabola.

However, I noticed I was getting a better signal boost when I brought the range extender 2.7cm further away from the antennas. So, I extended the mounts by 2.7cm. Give it a try and see what works best for you!

The signal booster is giving me at least a 1,500-2,000 feet boost. I need to perform another test, as a I forgot to note down the exact range difference. However, I did send my drone out far enough that when I removed the signal booster, I was immediately disconnected from my drone. So it does work!!

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 1

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.20mm Layer Height

Infill:

20%

Notes:

If you're using MakerBot Desktop, you'll likely need to use a raft. I almost never use a raft, but because of the beveled edges of this design, you should probably use one.

I used MakerBot Desktop Standard settings (0.2mm layer height) and changed it to 20% infill since you'll want some internal strength since a screw will be going through it.

comments.text: what do I need to buy to make this work my controller only has one a.tenna
comments.author: jafet420

comments.text: Hey, what kind of controller do you have that only has one antenna? Anyway, do you know if this 3D printed mount fits on the controller? If so, you can print just one mount for the one antenna. Then for the curved signal booster which has two curved structures connected to each other (for 2 antennas): either cut the design in half so you only print one curved structure, or print the design and get a knife or a dremel or something and slice the thing in half.

description.text:
Prop guard for the estes proto x fpv

Modified this prop guard to suit my own needs, wanted it to wrap up and around the blades, plus I gave it feet on the top to land on in the event the drone flips all the way over.

Prints from shapeways and stratasys objet 500 both worked great, although I didn't initially realize I would also need a mirrored version. Based on the TIGHT version from:

ProtoX_FPV_BladeGuard_002.stl - rounded a few more corners for "aerodynamics", I doubt it helps at these scales though.

3D model made with http://jthatch.com/Terrain2STL/

A re-mix of kazysd's "Piano".
Slightly reduced size of legs to fit into recess in piano body.
Added a more detailed keyboard. A very nice model. Printed on
a Solidoodle 3. For those of you who don't look at the instructions menu, I advise using support on the piano body only, to fill the voids the legs fit into. The rear one did not bridge over without support for me.

I advise using support on the piano body to fill the inside of the leg hollow's. Easy to remove.
Must glue parts together, keyboard to body, legs to body, lid to body, soundboard to body and support stick to body.

comments.text:
Guys, listen up...if you are trying to print the keyboard section, start with black, when you see the white key parts start to print, pause and change filament to white...when the black keys begin to print, change back to black to finish this part. All single extruder multicolor prints are done in this way. NO PAINT! The strings were printed in gold abs, body and part of keyboard in black abs, white abs for keys.
Have a solidoodle 3 and use only abs on my machine. Pla will also work with the same process. Most of my models are designed to be printed in multicolors with a SINGLE EXTRUDER machine. Give it a try.

author: winks

print_settings.Notes:: Easy prints... on a well set up machine with PLA the parts should slide together and rotate to lock / unlock with minimal effort.

title: Interlocking Stackerz
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Interlocking Stackerz are easy prints of a clever modular storage and transport solution that features interlocking sections of different sizes to suit an endless array of applications. Use them to store and/or transport anything and everything small including nuts / bolts / screws to medication etc.

This version has a Smooth Sidewall. A "Ribbed Sidewall" version is available at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1578855. This changes the appearance of them and can also make is easier for some people to grip to lock / unlock.

There is also a fun / novelty version called 'ROCKETZ' you can find at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1563995

The mechanism is simple... just push two parts together and rotate 120° to lock in place. Additional parts lock together in the same way... reverse to unlock and separate the parts.

Interlocking Stackerz provide a simple solution to storing and transporting things. For example, store a range of nuts / bolts / screws in them and they become a 'grab and go' item so you can take what you need with you without a second thought.... and different items are in different layers to keep the separate.

The internal diameter is the same for all parts (60mm at standard scale). The .stl files provided are as follows:

  • Cap
  • Layer / Low (15mm high storage area)
  • Layer / Medium (25mm high storage area)
  • Layer / High (50mm high storage area)
  • Base / Low (15mm high storage area)
  • Base / Medium (25mm high storage area)
  • Base / High (50mm high storage area)

Print the parts required to make up your ideal configuration in the colors of choice... color coding makes it easy to find what you have stored way.

Interlocking Stackerz are easy prints that do not need any support. On a well set up, accurate machine well sliced files should provide a snug fit between parts that still lets them turn to lock / unlock without much effort.

Please refer to the print settings and images for additional information.... and post photos of your Interlocking Stackerz in use.

Note: If you like this check out the rest of my practical and fun designs!

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Standard / 0.20mm

Infill:

2 Shells / 15% or more infill

Notes:

Easy prints... on a well set up machine with PLA the parts should slide together and rotate to lock / unlock with minimal effort.

Just push together and rotate to lock in place...

If your Interlocking Stackerz are tight to join / turn this is most likely due to machine and/or slicing app capability. Try increasing the scale uniformly by 3 - 5% to increase clearances. You can also give the locking parts a quick spray with silicone lubricant to make them slide together and rotate more easily.

comments.text: Thanks for your comment. There are only three stops that are evenly places around each joint so it should be 120 degrees(you can check this for yourself on the print. . If yours is getting tight at 90 degrees then your slicing app and/or machine is printing the joint with insufficient clearance. This is why some people find the joints a bit loose... I have to try and accommodate different slicing apps and machines so they print well for almost everyone. Looser ids safe for cases such as yours... unfortunately this is a fact of 3D printing life. No slicing app or printer prints exactly the same as another brand/model.

author: Kiraklis

description.text: https://youtu.be/xiucg9Zd2SY

Printer:

HE3D DLT-600

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25

Infill:

13%
A test printing

I purchased my TOM in order to build 3D objects, of course.  I've designed most of my objects to max-out the X and Y limits of the build platform (I originally had the ABP, but removed it in lieu of the HBP... because it increases your build height and provides a flatter build surface.  I'm interested in build capacity & quality, not printing things as fast as I can).
I measured my build platform, and found that it is 120mm X by 120mm Y... however, I have the HBP with hex bolts at 4 corners and self-adhesive aluminum tape on the platform.  So my actual "theoretical" build area should be approximately 120mm X by 102mm Y (between the hex-bolt heads).  But MANY of my larger prints (although designed to fit in a 120mm x 102mm space) were over-limiting on the X and/or Y axes.  
Most times, the X axis limited out either by hitting the X- limit switch, or by making horrible noises when it tried to travel past the physical X+ limits of the machine.  My machine has never limited-out on the Y- travel (where the Y- limit switch is, toward the rear of the machine), and has only seldomly maxed-out on Y+, which (again) makes horrible noises.
So I've been unable to print a few "things" due to unavailable area.  Perhaps there are ways to so-called "overcome" this in Skeinforge... but I don't want a solution to the problem that minimizes my print area.  I want a solution that uses the ENTIRE print area (and yes, I do have an aluminum build platform on the way... which will solve SOME of my problems, but not ALL of them).
I've attached a DXF file showing my HBP movements.  I measured all axes of my printer, based on positions from the limit switches (using 0.01mm increment jog mode on my Gen-4 interface).  I positioned each axis until the red limit switch LED light was off.  Then I jogged every axis (individually) to see what it's maximum amount of travel was (before the horrible sounds at the end of physical travel happened).  I measured everything with digital calipers.
My Thing-O-Matic has 116mm of X travel, 123mm of Y travel, and 125mm of Z travel.  So theoretically, my "HOME" position for X should be 58mm, and my "HOME" position for Y should be 61.5mm.
But this is not true on my TOM.  If centered on 58mmX and 61.5mmY, my build platform is not centered on the nozzle.
At full X- (RIGHT, with limit switch off), my nozzle is approximately 5.6 mm inside of the left edge of the build platform.
At full X+ (LEFT, mechanical limits only), my nozzle is approximately 2.3mm past the right edge of the build platform.
At full Y- (REAR, limit switch off), my nozzle is approximately 7.81mm past the front edge of the build platform.
At full Y+ (FORWARD, mechanical limits only), my nozzle is approximately 5.75mm in from the rear edge of the build platform.
In short, my build area is limited by incorrect geometry.  So I drew a quick 2D CAD file (included with this first post) to show the geometry of my TOM's build platform, in relation to the nozzle.  In short, by nozzle (and probably most of all TOM owner's nozzles, if I'm guessing right) needs to be moved back about 6.78mm, and to the left about 3.95mm.
Please... BY ALL MEANS prove me wrong!  ;)
To correct this, I either have to build an entirely new build platform (which would be very time-consuming (yet possible with a lot of hours behind my Dremel tools, since I don't own a laser cutter yet)), or to simply reposition the nozzle itself.
NOTE:  YOU WILL NEED A RELIABLE & ACCURATE SET OF CALIPERS (preferrably digital and able to read in MM) IN ORDER TO ACCOMPLISH THIS TASK.
This is BY NO MEANS a complete project... and one I wish I didn't have to do, to be honest.  But all TOM owners should be aware of these things, I think.
I'll post more info when I have more info.
Thanks, guys....

PLEASE do not use these instructions until you've measured your TOM's full travel capacity (in all axes) and compared those measurements to the center of your build platform.  
My measurements (depending on the position(s) of the build platform were somewhat tricky to get, and I had to "eyeball" one edge of the caliper to the center of the nozzle in the X and Y positions.  In my CAD file, you'll see that I accounted for this human error using "construction lines", which are dimensioned.  No error (in any axis... but the focus here is on the X and Y stages, not the Z stage) is more than 1mm.  I took the cumulative error and divided it in both the X and Y stages in order to calculate the best "new position" for my extruder.
In the worst-case scenario (which I will also calculate using CAD) I will have to re-position my X- limit switch (to the right, just a few milimeters) in order to solve the entire travel area issue.    
I assume that (since they are laser-cut packages), that most of you who follow my advice will also find that your TOMs are NOT properly centered, and not physically capable of BEING centered through software.
As soon as I've corrected my extruder position (along with a small handfull of mechanical/aesthetic upgrades to the extruder platform)... with minimal physical modification to the machine, and something that ALL Thing-O-Bot owners can do.

comments.text: I will also note that I've NEVER used the "homing" or "wait until heats are up to temperature" Gcodes on my machine, because they have never worked.  I manually delete that part of the code from every successful build I've made, so far (TOM owner for about a month... still learning about the damn thing).  :)
comments.author: clintkc

comments.text: You should probably chat with support -- the calibration and homing routines are one of those things that "should just work," and really make printing easier. Wait for temperature too... sounds like you plugged in the HBP wrong. The three pins of the connector line up with the 5v, signal, ground pins on the EC... simple answer is to make sure the empty pin-slot is facing the processor. I think it is "white, green, black, empty" in that order. If it's still reading 130C, then the thermistor is broken!
comments.author: clintkc

comments.text: Ditto what Lenbok wrote re. getting help via the mailing list being better than via Thingiverse comments.
comments.author: clintkc

comments.text: Here's a specific support troubleshooting link: http://support.makerbot.com/entries/20695918-my-build-platform-is-126-degreeshttp://support.makerbot.com/en...
comments.author: clothbot

comments.text: Your 130c problem for you platform is normally caused by having your temp connector from your build platform plugged into the wrong connectors on your Extruder Controller board. It's the cable that plugs into the middle of your Extruder Controller controller board on the grouping of pins. Check the picture on the build wiki.
comments.author: clintkc

comments.text: Have you tried asking your questions on the makerbot operators google group / mailing list? That would seem a better place than here.
comments.author: clintkc

title: Printrbot LC V2 Conversion : Metal Gear Extruder + Bowden + E3D Hotend

description.text:
This is a conversion kit for the following parts :
  • E3D Hotend : http://e3d-online.com/ourshop/prod_2781400-E3Dv5-All-metal-HotEnd-175mm-Direct-Extrusion.html
  • Metal Gear System Extruder : http://www.reprapsource.com/en/shop/list/201
  • Bowden cable
    • It should work with the bowden provided with the E3D hotend, just check the pneufit thread diameter. Be careful with your printer calibration, especially for the carriage : any misalignment will "block" the carriage on the rods. The extruder placement I chose was not the wiser : it is a bit painful to change the filament. Finally, many thanks to ajd4096 for his quick fit carriage scad file, and to Joachim Glauche for the extruder design (found here : https://github.com/Joaz/machine_parts/tree/master/mgs_prusa)

If you want to customize a bit :
  • x-carriage.scad contains everything for the carriage part.
  • extruder.scad and extruder_idler.scad contains the adapted extruder. Those files depend on configuration.scad, shapes.scad, lib-teardrop.scad and nema_motor.scad, be sure to have them in the same folder.

author: jojoalex

description.text:
As some other 2020 mounting plates for The Toranado Precision Geared 1.75mm Extruder (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1246951) licencing do not allow any derivatives and do not use Mini V Wheels, I decided to make my own.

RepRap is about making self-replicating machines, and making them freely available for the benefit of everyone.

I don't design things for this hobby of mine to make money, so, if anyone decides to change anything, all I ask is that you give me a shout out.

It is a mix of the Openbuilds Mini V Gantry Plate (http://openbuildspartstore.com/mini-v-gantry-plate/) and the OneZ-i3 X belt anchor bracket (http://www.openbuilds.com/builds/onez-i3.3389/). Just print in the orientation shown, the design does not need any support as there is a thin layer at the boundary of the two different wheel mounting hole sizes. The TPGE should be attached using dome headed screws to ensure they do not bind on then 2020 rail.

The photos are of a trial piece to show the Toranado M3 mounting holes and the M5 wheel bolt holes.

UPDATE 12 May 2016:

When I first mounted the TPGE I found that the mounting holes where slightly misaligned. I have updated the STL to more accurately position the mounting holes.

I only use design tools that are freely available on the internet, mostly because I can't afford to do anything else. This thing was designed with Tinkercad and Sketchup. View it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/5pzGMRPXnO7

title: PiGRRL Zero Raspberry Pi Zero Gameboy

description.text:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UAIILlANNj4

UPDATE The PiGRRL Zero case has been split into four pieces for printing on smaller beds! - Check the case-split.zip archive

You've seen PiGRRL, Super Game Pi, PiGRRL Pocket, PiGRRL 2 and now... it's time for PiGRRL Zero!

In this project, we'll turn the elusive $5 Raspberry Pi Zero into portable game console!

Features
-Retropie 3.7 Emulation Station: SNES, NES, SEGA, N64, and many many more!
-14 Buttons, including D-Pad, L & R shoulder, Start/Select, A, B, X, Y and two extras.
-2.2" Adafruit PiTFT 320x240 Color Display
-Landscape portable console format

The USB female jack allows you to add any peripherals to the Raspberry Pi Zero, such as a WiFi or Bluetooth adapter, USB keyboard or mouse, USB Audio Adapter or USB Hub.

Check out our full step-by-step tutorial:
https://learn.adafruit.com/pigrrl-zero

"You've seen PiGRRL, Super Game Pi, PiGRRL Pocket, PiGRRL 2 and now... it's time for PiGRRL Zero!"
Which ones have sound? I want to learn about Pi and electronics so this seems like a great project.
comments.author: Martin_S

comments.text: They all have audio except this one because the pi zero doesn't have audio out. Hope it helps :)

comments.text: Have you thought about making files for a 3.5 or 5 inch screen? This seems awfully small.  And why no audio?
comments.author: tfrost1980

comments.text: the pi zero doesnt has audio natively. you would either have to add a i2s dac or you have to make it like the raspberry pi foundation is doing it on every other pi: with some capacitors and some resistors. adafruit has a guide for this

comments.text: Thanks for that info, would this be suitable? I ask because its so cheap

comments.text: Nop, you need to search for I2S (Inter-IC Sound) and not (Inter-Integrated Circuit).
comments.author: tfrost1980

comments.text: So I've got everything together and working besides the button pad boards I'm still waiting on. Everything fits well, except for the screen. It sits quite deep from the upper part of the case. There is a 1-2mm gap where the screen sits low in the housing. I think the offsets are fine since the screen buttons sit properly and activate well, but maybe the lip around the screen should have been just a hair deeper. It still looks okay once the screen is on, but the gap is a little distracting. I don't really see this problem in the example build pics, so just wondering if there's something I might have got wrong? Maybe I should alter the model? Any thoughts? Could I stick something behind the actual display to push it forward a bit on the ptft board? Maybe something to act as a trim piece?
comments.author: ExcessRope

comments.text: Ah, it's possible the screen is being secured to the PCB with double-sided scotch tape, as opposed to foam tape. Sometimes our kitting team runs out of materials and ops in for different tape.
comments.author: ExcessRope

comments.text: That sounds like the exact problem! Bummer, but as you said, an easy fix. I'll try and get some foam tape and get her fixed up. Thanks so much for the quick reply Noe! I can't wait for my button PCBs to finish this project up!
comments.author: adafruit

comments.text: is there a tutorial or other content that covers the work flow of eagle PCB to 3D?  It looks there is a fusion 360 gallery with some of the PCB's.
comments.author: IonEwe

comments.text: Yep! I put together a tutorial video on our YouTube channel here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QjyWp5BAAVM&list=PLjF7R1fz_OOVsMp6nKnpjsXSQ45nxfORb&index=14
comments.author: IonEwe

comments.text: I was thinking more along the lines of the Eagle IDF-export utility to step file. But good to know the DXF is a "complicated".  IDF export requires a HEIGHT attribute (boxes), library of 3D parts (no idea how that works) or post work to replace parts for better detail (most likely). I also use the caliper method now and then. Some of the PCBs in the gallery looked so go I thought the where done with the IDF export.
comments.author: adafruit

comments.text: Nice project!
comments.author: LuisDUgena

comments.text: there are already measurements of the pi zeros consumption, which are similar to the a+ ones. i would think its around the same as shooting video, so around 200 mah @ 5V which is 1W. taking the circuitry into perspective it would be maybe around 1.1-1.2W ,on the lipos side. This means the power consumption is around 400mah @ 3.7V. That means the Lipo would last 5H, but 4 would be better, because you dont want to drain it completely
comments.author: LuisDUgena

comments.text: Cool, thank you!
comments.author: MatNow

comments.text: I'm in the process of printing the buttons and dpad now, and it occurred to me that I might want to print with a different % of infill.  It's not mentioned in the instructions... should I be printing at 100%?
comments.author: Gandarewa

comments.text: I ended up printing everything at 50% infill with 3 outer shells. Everything still feels quite strong and I don't perceive any problems. Most of the tiny pins and such in the case are solid anyways with the 3 shells, so I expect it to be alright. I'll certainly let you all know if I have any problems.
comments.author: Gandarewa

comments.text: Great tutorial! I have only 2 suggestions. One just add some text that details where the 26AWG wire is used in the build instead of the 30AWG wire. If this is someones first build they may not know which wire size to use where.  The second please add information on using the USB audio connector. I thought in your layer by layer video you were working on integrating it into the build and it is included in the BOM for the build.
comments.author: jusrr009

comments.text: Thank you! We have considered your suggestions and added them to the guide. There's now a new page that explains usage and extras.
comments.author: jusrr009

comments.text: if i modded the design, could i add a battery cover so i can ditch the powerboost 1000c? (and just take out the battery when i need to charge)
comments.author: JackJ106

comments.text: Sure! Just connect a 5V battery to the microUSB power port from Raspberry Pi Zero.
comments.author: JackJ106

comments.text:
Wait, wouldn't that fry the PI? dosnt the pi zero use 1.5V?
EDIT: oh, i see. the powerboost increases the charge or whatever to 5V. but still wouldnt it fry the pi? sorry. im new-ish to electronics.
comments.author: adafruit

comments.text: Pi zero uses 5V that's why the powerboost steps up the voltage from the 3.7V lipo battery to 5V so the pi can operate. 5V is where it should be to operate normally.
comments.author: JackJ106

comments.text: thank you very mutch! im just used to the 1.5V of my pi 1, model B.
comments.author: liv04soccer

comments.text: Anybody have any tips for making the buttons work with PLA instead of Ninjaflex? My printer can't print flexible materials, but I've printed up the buttons in PLA. Will they work in PLA for this project? Anybody else use PLA buttons for previous PiGRRL projects? Should I cut the buttons apart? Any tips or help would be appreciated, thanks!
comments.author: ExcessRope

comments.text: Shouldn't be a problem in PLA, you'll have to put the shoulder buttons in place before closing it and they won't feel rubbery but that's about the only difference
comments.author: ExcessRope

comments.text: Great, thanks! I was just worried about the d-pad and the ABXY buttons pressing more than one actuator if they don't flex. I guess I'll find out soon enough. Cheers!
comments.author: Ampersands

comments.text:
the Dpad should be fine since you won't need to push 2 opposite directions at the same time and the ABXY buttons are split into 2 pairs so they'll be fine too.
Edit: just realised the files uploaded aren't the ones used in the pics, the ABXY buttons might be problem unless you split them into 2 pairs
comments.author: ExcessRope

comments.text: So I should split them? Because the STL file available is a single circle with all 4 buttons. I know their example make has the buttons in two different colors, but I thought that was just for looks. I think I'll try them as a single part (since I've already printed them as such) and if it causes problems, perhaps I'll split it and print them again. Thanks again for the help.
comments.author: Ampersands

comments.text: Ampersands has great suggestions, although I haven't tried PLA buttons yet, I've heard some folks had success with other PiGRRL builds. I imagine the ABXY buttons could be split using a hobby knife (I used scissors to cut the ninjaflex ones). Let us know how it turns out :-)
comments.author: ExcessRope

comments.text: Well, got my PiGRRL Zero built! It's great, almost. The PLA ABXY and shoulder buttons work fine, but the d-pad is pretty horrible. The tft buttons work okay, but I think I'll likely cut them apart so they have less chance of pressing more than one actuator. I'm not sure how to go about fixing the d-pad though. Any ideas? I really wish I could print flex material, but my bowden tube delta printer just will not do it and I'd really rather avoid 3d hubs or the like just for a d-pad. You think there's a clever way to split the d-pad so pressing one direction doesn't push 3 directions? It's kind of weird that the ABXY buttons work so well and the d-pad doesn't since they're so similar. I guess it's just the way the force is applied to the buttons closer to the ends and guided by the individual holes?
comments.author: adafruit

comments.text: OK! So I put together a new DPad specifically for hard materials, you can grab it here and try it out: http://www.thingiverse.com/download:2456336
comments.author: ExcessRope

comments.text:
Thanks so much. I actually printed the buttons upside down and right-side-up. I like the top layer texture on the right-side-up one better and they both turned out pretty well with supports on, so I installed that one.
Good news, it seems to press the buttons independently just as expected. Bad news, while putting everything back together I managed to crack my micro sd card in half from pressure from the button pcb and some wires that got between them. Bummer :( I tried a different sd card and couldn't get anything except a white screen. I think I dorked that one up too somehow. I'm all out of micro sd cards, so I can't actually verify how well the buttons work, but they feel much better and more distinct. Thank you so much for your help with all this. I can't wait to get back up and running. I'll update when I can try again, but I think this new d-pad will work out just fine. Great job!
On another note, these things don't like getting taken apart and put back together too much, lol. The snap-fit edges are awesome, but I've managed to snap a few of my pcb supports inside with all the tinkering, so I may end up having to re-print the case. Nature of 3d-printing I suppose. Still, this is an awesome project. Thanks again Noe.
comments.author: adafruit

comments.text: Thanks Adafruit! I will try to use the buttons as solid pieces first. If that causes any problems, I think I will cut them apart and perhaps use a pieces of tape or something to keep them together but basically integrate a hinge to allow for independent movement. Either way, I will post results. Thanks again for a fantastic project. I can't wait for my button pad boards to get cut and arrive. Everything else should be here tomorrow and I've already printed all the parts. Everything came out great, except I will have to ream out the holes for all the buttons just a hair. The tolerances were super tight there, but they all still fit. The buttons just don't move freely yet, nothing a little needle file can't fix. The case snaps together perfectly though and feels very secure. I'd post pics, but I want to get it all built first. I'm so stoked!
comments.author: adafruit

comments.text: The hard D-Pad worked for me after I placed a M3 Nylon washer between the button board and each of the standoffs.
comments.author: ExcessRope

comments.text: That's a good idea, thanks. The new d-pad worked better, but it's still a little bit picky. I'll try the washer and see how it goes. Cheers!

Giving the design a test run this weekend. Thanks for the original model, BullseyeBody.

I remixed it by chopping off most of the pointed roof to a flat surface and removing your website name.

2017 UPDATE: After getting almost no bees the first summer, this year I got probably 25-30 of those buggers!!!

Be the life of the party with the super extra double awesome can clip handle. The can clip handle will keep you from getting the dreaded cold hand while you party with your friends. But wait, that's not all! You can even customize the handle for your event or personalize it so you know which can is yours. No more accidentally grabbing your friend's can or the can with all the trash in it. So don't wait. Download a copy of this easy printing miracle device and print it!
Note: the can will still stand up just fine on on it's own when you set it down. It does wobble a little though.
Update 10/11/2013 Added in a option to make the text bold for printers which have trouble fine detail.
Update 10/17/2013 Rounded out the edges at the top and bottom to reduce concentrating the stress when bent. I'll print a new example once I try out a couple other changes.
Update 2/7/2014 I changed the can height default from 122mm to 125mm. Now that I've correctly calibrated my machine this height seems to work best.
Update 10/14/2014 I added the option to used raised text instead of inset.

If you want some text on the handle, use the customizer.  If you don't need text, just download the blank handle.  Don't change the can height unless you need to.  From my experimentation so far, this works on most 12 oz U.S. cans.  You can use a low a fill when printing since there isn't really any strength required.  I use 20%.  I've only printed it in ABS, but I suspect PLA should work fine.  Be sure to let it cool before trying it on your can or you could warp it.  It is suppose to require a little tension to clip to the can.  You will find it is easiest to clip the bottom before the top.

comments.text: Would it be possible to extend the bottom of the handle for a complete base, or ring, that the can would sit in to reduce or remove the "wobble" from setting the can down? Or would that make it too bulky for the simplicity of the handle?
comments.author: Enkidu

comments.text: I made a more stable version. You can find it here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:172274http://www.thingiverse.com/thi....
comments.author: Enkidu

comments.text: A ring on the bottom was my original plan.  I just haven't been able to figure out how to design it so it prints nicely without support (except possibly only going for half a circle).  Once a structure leaves the plane of the handle you'll need to push the handle off the bed to make room for it and that requires support.  The current design was actually just a test as I tried to figure out how to design the base.  I was surprised it wobbled so little so I published this as it is.
comments.author: Enkidu

comments.text: A 2 piece version could work. Might need some glueing but would be a nice option
comments.author: Eckerput

comments.text: That's actually a really good idea.  I've been experimenting recently with snap together pieces which could help too.  A flat round base could print quickly. I'll try working something up when I have a some time.
comments.author: M3Design

comments.text: Something like a sliding t-slot would work great i asume AND would be printable even without supports, although it would raise the whole thing a few mils
comments.author: Eckerput

comments.text: I tried customizing the can holder (using a cube X) and the lettering turned out terrible.  I have found that the lettering does not look good on the cube X printer (on most things that have lettering though).
comments.author: dkugler

comments.text: On the off chance this will help, I added a "bold" option to the lettering.  It makes the carve outs about 2x wider.  It may help make the letters clearer for printers that have problems with that level of detail.
comments.author: dkugler

comments.text: There is always the uncustomized one of course, but that's a lot less fun.  If you have any idea why the letters look bad I'd be up for trying some changes.  I can't really make them any larger though or the descenders don't fit on the handle.  On my Printrbot printer I found the filament switch just after the lettering starts (like the example photo) makes them much more visible.
comments.author: dkugler

comments.text: It is a little bit too large for European cans (330ml), but some hot water helped me :)
comments.author: Naalis

comments.text: I added in a variable for can height to the customizer in case your can varies a bit from the ones I used.  If you know how tall your can is, you can adjust the height to get perfect fit.

This is a remix lightened M3 UK early Stuart I modified for myself and thought other people might like it. It is hollowed out with a shorter turret basket and the MG taken off. I have plenty of spare 30cal MGs from PSC halftrack packs to use and the shorter turret basket and light hull will save time and materials.
Update: I added a rear sprue to the hull which should allow it to be printed rightside up without supports. I also cut another portion of the hull out to ease printing. The rear part should snap off easily (haven't tried it yet) and print faster.

title: TS 2040 Vertical Rail Carriage for Prusa i3, Toranado for TEVO Tarantula V2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
UPDATED 2016/07/21: So after some further discussion on Facebook, the correct dimensions were provided and I have updated this carriage. I apologize for the previous error. I have created 2 models. The A model corrects the dimensions of the original. The B model has additional M3 holes to allow mounting the NEMA17 directly to the carriage.

If you make this and have it working, please show a Make of it. If you still have issues, please let me know and provide dimensions so I can properly correct it. Thanks.

I designed this carriage for the TEVO Tarantula so it can mount the Toranado 1.1 Precision Geared Extruder found at:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1246951

The 4 hole version should also be compatible with the Prusa i3 attachments.

This carriage is designed to be vertically mounted on the TEVO Tarantula 2040 rail and will only work on like printers. I have been informed that the TEVO Tarantula's rails may not be 100% compatible with the OpenBuilds rails. The TEVO rails are not V-slot like the OpenBuilds rails and so it will not be compatible with OpenBuilds 2040 rails.

I do not have a TEVO Tarantula so I am unable to test this. However, the same wheel spacing was used on my other 2020 carriages so it should work.

This is not intended to be a swap out for the stock TEVO Tarantula which is mounted horizontally by design.

The screws to attach the Toranado should be round with short heads so that the screws don't interfere with the rail.

There is a very thin layer in the larger holes that can be cut or drilled out so that a bridge can be created to print the counter-sink without supports.

Use M5 screws with OpenBuilds wheels. Requires 2 eccentric spacers for the larger holes.

Prefer to use a stiff filament plastic like ASA or ABS or similar.

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Requires bridging.

comments.text: do you have a picture of it on your machine please
comments.author: Westey

comments.text: BUT, you can check out the version I have of it on my machine at this thing:
comments.author: Westey

comments.text: No, because I don't have a TEVO machine.  :)
comments.author: Westey

comments.text: Looks like missing holes for the endstops and belt
comments.author: basestring

comments.text: The vertical protrusions in the image are for the belt. I wasn’t asked to make holes for an end stop. Aren’t endstops usually on the rail? Why add unnecessary wires to the carriage?
comments.author: basestring

comments.text: Dumb questions: How does this mount? Which holes to the wheels go in and which mounts the Toranado? Can it mount a left and a right at the same time? I'm afraid I'm a bit lost as to how to use it.
comments.author: jmpinc

comments.text: This is a single carriage.  It can mount a right or a left.  I could probably create a new dual mount. The wheels go in the outer corners.  The inner holes are for the Prusa attachments.  The one file also includes mounts in the pattern for a NEMA motor as requested by someone.  I don't have a TEVO so I can't show it in operation.
comments.author: jmpinc

comments.text: Would you be will to share .stp (step file) or other solid CAD file that can be manipulated?
comments.author: puma1824

comments.text: What do you need done?
comments.author: puma1824

comments.text: Need to change the spacing to accommodate Tevo larger wheels, move the accessory mounting holes to center a Nema17 w/Titan extruder,  and add a mount for the end-point switch.
comments.author: timeshell

comments.text: TEVO doesn't use openbuilds wheels?
comments.author: puma1824

comments.text: They use the larger wheels.  This looks like it's spaced for the smaller openbuilds wheels.
comments.author: timeshell

comments.text: This wasn't designed for the openbuilds minis.  It was designed for the regular openbuilds wheels.
comments.author: puma1824

comments.text: Unfortunately spacing seems off.  Maybe the Tevo wheels are slightly different.
comments.author: timeshell

comments.text: I made this thing with 123D Design.  I can only provide the file it creates.
comments.author: timeshell

comments.text: Cool,  I use 123D Design as well.  Can you upload them here ? :)
comments.author: timeshell

comments.text: Just so everyone knows the holes on this model are too close to use the included tevo wheels.
comments.author: jonnova69

comments.text: What kind of wheels are they?  What is the variation?
comments.author: jonnova69

comments.text: They are just black delrin wheels but they must be larger in diameter than the open build wheels you designed this part for. I can provide you with dimensions if you would like.
comments.author: timeshell

comments.text: Sure.  I'll see if I can make a variant for them.  Pictures would be nice too.
comments.author: jonnova69

title: Turnigy Action Camera Go-Pro 'Syle' Mount for Quadcopters

description.text:
This is a simple mount to allow you to use a Turnigy action camera on models that expect to have GoPro style mounts. We're using it here on a Nova Pro from HobbyKing.

Print one of the bases and two of the arms, use a paperclip as the hinge.

This can be used to mount the camera below or above the mount point and still get to the power and action switches.

Thanks for looking, happy flying and printing!

I was looking through openscad documentation and wanted to make something using the minkowski() command. Hopefully this turned out well. (also let me know if you see the customizer option, when I uploaded the file it didn't show up) Next project I'll mess around with the hull() command

Also the image isn't quite working yet. Hope to get it working soon

minkowski explained 
minkowski(){
    cylinder(h = .0000000001, r = diameter_of_coaster/2-height_of_coaster,$fn = resoultion,center=true);
    sphere(height_of_coaster/2,$fn=resoultion,center=true);
}

so how (I think) minkowski works it it attempts to combine the items in it, so in this case it attempts to make a cylinder with a sphere revolved around the outside. it also adds the heights of the two together, which is why the cylinder height is set to a very small number. (if it is 0 it doesn't make a cylinder so you make it very close to zero) it also adds the sphere's diameter to each side of the cylinder, so that is why it has - the diameter of the sphere when making the radi of the cylinder.

I have a couple of tall, heavy shelves that need a bracket that anchors them to the wall. I still need to print and test these brackets. I'm guessing a very high infill will be needed to ensure these pieces are strong and stable. UPDATE: I just printed a set for my shelves and they came out very well and so far are providing some serious stability. Wall anchors are needed for drywall application and either one or two screw anchoring depending on how stable you want this bracket to be. I printed these at a bigger size with an infill of 75%.

title: Universal Ultimaker 2(+) Spool Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Now updated to V2. (changelog below)

This is a universal Spool Holder for the Ultimaker 2(+) and is easy detachable while holding a spool. This makes it easy for people who don't have good access to the back of their printer.

The Spool Holder can hold spools with an inside diameter from 39mm up to 70mm and a maximum width between 95mm and 125mm (depending on the inside diameter).

Technical information:
The tread used to clamp the spool is a multi pitch thread (multiple starts, like a jar of jam) so the travel per revolution is 3 times as much. This makes putting on the nut easier and you don't have to make as much revolutions to clamp the spool.

Make one of every part except for the "Plastic Bearing" you need to of those.

You also need:

  • M8 threaded rod 150mm long.
  • 2x M8 nuts to assemble.
  • If possible I recommend Tread locker (LOCTITE) on the nuts.

Changelog Update V2: I made the tolerances bigger so there should be no more problems with parts that don't fit. I also improved the strength of the Threaded Cone V2 so it wont brake when you tighten the treads hard. This resulted in an increase of the minimum inside spool-diameter that can fit (was 33 now is 39).

In the "Files V1 (old model).zip" you can find the files before the update.
I also uploaded the .gcode files I used to print the V2 model. I know these files work on Ultimaker's 2 and 2+ (Maybe on the Ulitmaker 3 as well)

I used the Low friction spool holder by Sneakypoo as inspiration.

The Solidworks and step files are also available.

https://youtu.be/ye2tGyrJXD0 (this video is taken from the old V1 model, the new one works just as well)

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I used Cura 2.5.0 to slice.

I printed everything in PLA, the tolerances in this model don't work with ABS.

General settings I used:

  • Nozzle diameter 0.4mm.
  • Speed 60mm/s for all parts except for ''Long Tube'' and ''Short Tube'' use 30mm/s for those.

    Print all parts in the the original orientation.

    Use support for the part ''Printer mount''.

    It is also recommended to print the parts: "Printer mount" and "T-piece" with 100% infill. When you use very heavy spools this is NECESSARY.

    If you use Cura to slice:

    Slice the the parts ''Long Tube'' and ''Short Tube'' with a shell thickness of 1.1mm so you don't get infill lines. (this is faster and the quality will be better)

    You can also use my .gcode files.

comments.text: Love the design but I can't get it to work, and I'm not sure what's going on. Have an Ultimaker 3 Extended, printed to the specs listed in the Readme and have multiple tolerance issues. 1. The T-piece prints slightly too large to slide into the printer mount.  Not too bad on it's own as I suspect I could sand it down   2. The Spool Nut prints with either a thread pitch or scale too tight for the threaded tube, if I print the entire size it jams on the threads, if I print half of the cone it's a firm fit. I've tried at 100%, 101% and 102.5% to be sure.  3. The Threaded Cone in the orientation in the files is too fragile, when I tightened it the first time it snapped at the bottom threads. I'm in the process of trying to print horizontally to see if that increases thread strength as I've read on some forums.  **Would also love an INCH/US spec drawing as I'll have to sub a 5/16" for the M8 and not sure how good the fit will be.

comments.author: dema12co

comments.text: No change, the "fixed" Netfabb files had the same end result, the threads on the nut, cone and threaded tube will not work. I'll stick with the other threaded design.
comments.author: dema12co

comments.text: UPDATE** - I bought Simplify3D and out of pure OCD decided to try the "fixed" files from NetFabb (threaded tube and nut). I ran the first through at 100% and Medium quality, and it WORKED! albeit a bit tight on the nut, probably from some slop on the internal threads.  I upsized the nut to 101% and reprinted at high quality, and after a few passes with the nut to clean off the burrs it is almost perfect.  Out of curiosity I tried the previously printed threaded tube and nuts and found something odd.  The Simplify3D "fixed" nut printed at both 100% and 101%, worked for the most part on the Cura printed threaded tubes, they were just slightly tight at the middle, however the reverse is not true, the Cura nuts still do not work on the Simplify3D tubes....this leads me to believe that Cura doesn't like something in the Nut model that even Netfabb can't fix, but that Simplify3D either ignores or fixes during slicing...very interesting.  Lesson is, if you like this model, don't print with Cura....
comments.author: dema12co

comments.text: hey man. thx for the info. can you tell me witch version ov Cura you used ? because i only tested my design with Cura 15.04.6. Also did you print all the parts with 100% infill? because that can give a large tolerance increase in Cura.
comments.author: dema12co

comments.text: Happy to help, like the design.  I have the Ultimaker 3 Extended, so I'm using Cura 2.5.0 that Ultimaker provides for it, and bought S3D 3.1.1 to test.  I used 1.5mm layers, 1.1mm shell, 100% infill on the T-piece and printer mount only, 50% on the cone, and 20 or 25% on the rest.  I don't think it's the infill because the jam isn't at the beginning, it's a few turns in, it seems to be an issue in how it calculates the threads themselves on the nut.  Also of note, the original printed cone actually fit inside the threaded tube, but the outer nut did not.  I need to figure out how to print the threaded cone sideways now, as it will strengthen the threads and prevent the cracking I had before.

comments.text: Sorry to hear that you are disappointed. The tolerances are tight. But it will fit on a good calibrated printer. Apparently not all printers print dimensionality accurate.
comments.author: Kong_Engineering

comments.text:
The tolerances don't need to be tight. There is no reason for it, no advantage. You could have the nut go on loose with a locking nut behind it so it doesn't move and it would work perfectly.
If you do a refined version, loosen up the tolerances by a lot so you can accommodate all printing variances then actually lay out the item on the table in the sequence order on how it should be built. From the pictures, you can't tell where anything really truly goes. I like the design which is why i went for it but i'm going to have to re-design everything.

title: Phone Clip for Town & Country and Samsung Galaxy Grand

description.text:
Stock cd-based mounts interfere with the cupholders, so I created this clip to hold a Galaxy Grand (T-Mobile) in a Town & Country Limited (2001).

Print in ABS (so it won't get soft in the summer heat). Affix a piece of double-sided tape to the bottom of the mount (despite the barbs, it comes out too easily). Split the file and a locking key will be separate; install the locking key after it's installed for just a bit more holding-in-the-van power.

Hook the phone in the top and push the bottom back; it will lock. To unlock, lift the phone vertically just a bit and it will hop over the locking ridge.

Robo 3D

author: ThorMJ

title: Vaders Pi Case Assortment - Raspberry Pi B+/2/3

description.text:
Iam tired of choosing between premade simple pi cases that cannot be changed (or not without a lot of work). So i thought Ill design my own Pi Case.

Originally I was looking for a Case with a 40mm fanmount but most dont fit my needs. So I downloaded the original mechanical drawing of the Pi (on their homepage) and startet with calipers and an old Pi B+.

Got some neat ideas and this is work in Progress so stay tuned. There will be some awesome range of pi cases.

IF YOU HAVE ANY REQUEST PLS MESSAGE ME!

7th of May 2016

  • Added basic Pi cases
  • Added Case Stackers with Vents

8th of May 2016

  • Reuploaded Bottom Casehalfs with chamfered clips
  • Added Top casehalfs RectGrid and HoneycombGrid
  • Added Top casehalf Closed
  • Added bottomhalfs for Vesa 100 mounting
  • Added screwholes incase someone needs it more ridgit than clipping

9th of May 2016

  • Added RaspiCam Holders (Clip on Vents) for top and side mounting
  • Reuploaded Top Halfs with thicker standoffs between USB/LAN Port
  • Reuploaded Top Halfs again now taler because some heatsinks wont have clearance to the fan if mounted inside

10th of May 2016

  • Added some representing pictures

31th of July 2017

  • Added all Bottom Parts with Vents and 10mm Clearance for mounting Heatsinks. Thanks to Bob Morse (bmorse526) for the idea!

27th of August 2017

  • Added tops for hats (10mm more height) Thx linlar for the idea
  • Edited the screwholes away cause Hats wont fit

title: E3D Titan Bracket for Mendel90 with SUB-D Support

description.text:
Its like the standard E3D Titan Bracket (2mm between Extruder and Stepper), but for a smaller Stepper (42x42x20mm (Thanks to Thomas Sanladerer for the tip)). The standard stepper (Wantai 42BYGHW609L20P1-X2) is too big and much heavier than the 17HS08-1004S (you can order it at aliexpress.com).
You need also a X-Carriage with a larger hole (50mm).

I have create the bracket with tinkercad, so please dont judge me :D
I hope it is useful for someone.

comments.author: nimco123

comments.text: so I tested and it doesn't work with a 20mm or 25mm, and 3mm filament. The stepper was getting very very hot and losing steps. I tried adjusting current, but that was still not good.
comments.author: esprit1711

comments.text:
I had the same problem. Now, i have set the Vref Voltage from my DRV8225 Stepper driver to 0,55V to solve the problems (high temperature and losing steps).
I Dont know if its also necessary, but i put a 48 x 25mm Heat sink on the top of the Stepper.
I print since more than 5 months without any Stepper problems.

  • V2.0: introducing board
  • V2.1: fixed PLA board dimensions, removed corner, introduced edge instead
  • V2.2: added piece sets for 5x5 game, adjusted diamond for PLA

Gaming Pieces

There are files with pieces for both colors and different game sizes. Each file contains a Capstone and several Flatstones. Print the black and the white version to get all pieces:

  • Print the 5x5 files with a Capstone and 21 Flatstones for a 5x5 game.
  • Print the 6x6 files with a Capstone and 30 Flatstones for a 5x5 game.
  • Print the 5x5 and the 6x6 files to get two Capstones and 51 Flatstones for a 8x8 game (with one spare Flatstone).
Board
  • I've designed the board with different files for ABS (tight fit) and PLA (with a little space). The diamond file is the same for both filaments.
  • Board layouts can be found here: http://cheapass.com/games/tak
  • Hybrid board 5x5 will need:
    • 8x field black
    • 8x field white
    • 25x diamond
    • 16x side
    • 4x edge
  • Hybrid board 6x6 will need:
    • 9x field black
    • 16x field white
    • 36x diamond
    • 20x side
    • 4x edge

author: scr33tch

title: Ain't I A Real Woman? Exploring Womanhood

description.text:
(Look at photos in expanded view to see the whole thing!)

I was in a 3D Printing class this semester at Denison University, and for our final project we got to do whatever we wanted that we thought might be useful to people in some way, maybe with our academic department of choice. (I want to give a great big thank you to Laura Taalman [mathgrrl] for her help inspiring this as my final project!)

With the recent panic over which women are "real" enough to use women's bathrooms, I wanted to explore other ways in which we use a woman's physicality to determine her "womanhood status." So I made some figurines and stuck them to bathroom signs around campus! Each figure is a 3D person who I think is not adequately represented by the "triangle dress" woman or wheelchair figure on bathroom signs. "Woman 1" is fat, "Woman 2" has a form of dwarfism, and "Woman 3" is an amputee who uses forearm crutches.

What I also like about this project is that while I focused on women's signs, these figurines can be used in other cool ways to disrupt gender norms. I could have put each of these up on men's rooms signs; I could make two square frames and put the same figure in each, labeling one men's and one women's. Or I could put them on a sign that just said "bathroom" and see what people did....I like that people can play around with them.
I've really enjoyed the results so far, though the project has been very limited in scope based on time constraints. I'm hoping to leave them up on campus as long as I can, and it would be amazing to see these women, as well as all of your takes on them, pop up all over the place!

More specifics on the project and the figurines:
The title I gave this project is "Ain't I A Real Woman?" as a nod to the fact that race has long been a way we ascribe value to women through their bodies... And have you noticed how tiny people in wheelchairs are on these signs compared to the standing figures? Look at how big their heads are! It's as if this sign is reflecting our societal association with size and value, tellingly devaluing or infantilizing those in wheelchairs....I wanted my amputee figure to be active, since (aside from being tiny) wheelchair signs like this one often show the people sitting, as if in need of someone else to push them. And while that's super fine, making the assumption that people with disabilities automatically need the help of non-disabled people is not cool, yo.

What do you think? How could this project be better, or go further?

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

comments.text: It is a pictogram that was developed in conditions where the symbols best represented the scenario. Today they are a standard that metaphorically present a majority. Sure there are exceptions but it is like picking on the play/pause buttons or floppy disk save icon from days gone past.
comments.author: Granite

comments.text: This is an understandable attitude, but "there are exceptions" is a very different experience for you, vs. someone who is one of those exceptions.
comments.author: Granite

comments.text: This is very true. When it comes to the binary of gender segregated bathrooms it's very easy to distinguish male from female with the pictograms and that's what's important. I don't even remember being taught about them, it just always made sense that the skirted one is female and the trousered one is male.
comments.author: Granite

comments.text: That's kind of the issue with these sorts of things - they're often unacknowledged, and not taught. What about men who like to wear dresses or skirts? (Are those "Women's clothes?" What on earth does a piece of fabric have to do with a person's gender or sex?)
comments.author: AcrimoniousMirth

comments.text: It simply comes down to cultural norms. I’ve lived in East Africa, where people wear kikoi (like a robe) and the symbols are recognised and understood. And in Scotland, land of the kilts. That’s part of the power of iconography, we even had an entire bullshit class dedicated to the topic in my product design and engineering course.
comments.author: GeoMaciolek

title: Sega Saturn Rhea/Phoebe SD Card Tray

description.text:
AN UPDATED VERSION IS NOW AVAILABLE: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2010525

The Rhea and Phoebe are SD card adapters that replace the ever failing disc drives in Sega Saturn consoles. These are great devices but they leave a very large space open inside the console meaning you can easily, accidentally drop your SD card inside the console and be forced to disassemble it to get the card back. This SD card Tray is designed to fit on top of the Rhea or Phoebe device and seal off the inside of the console making it impossible to drop your SD card inside through an open lid.

There are two STL files, one includes a set of 4 slots to allow you to store additional SD cards in the space available, the slots are staggered to allow easier gripping and they're placed such that when the lid is closed it will keep the from falling out even if the console is turned upside down. The file without these slots is simply for people who are not interested in this feature.

Fitment has been tested on VA0 and VA1 console revisions with a Rehea version 3.1. Other console and Rhea/Phoebe version should work as they are dimensionally similar, however if you use this file I would appreciate a comment confirming fitment on other revisions.

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

Supports are necessary as the entire section that fits over the Rhea/Phoebe device has about a 2mm overhang. This is a low stress part and the only critical dimensions are the rear mounting holes so the material, quality and other settings are not important.

comments.text:
I just got mine in today, and was able to install it with no problems. Very nice work, man.
It looks much better, and now I don't have to worry about my card falling into the system.

It doesn't matter though because V2 fixes this completely for all Saturn versions. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2010525

This hinge uses a joint design that's unique to additive manufacturing, you couldn't make a hinge like this any other way. It's also sized to fit nicely on a 20XX-style extrusion so the pivot point is right next to the outer edge of the extrusion and will pivot a full 90+ degrees in either direction.

It has M3 holes for mounting which tend to come out at 2.5mm diameter on print, making them suitable for tapping to M3, reaming to 3mm, or using as-is with #4 wood screws, depending on what hardware you have available and what you're mounting to.

There are two version of the hinge available, the normal tolerance version with ~.2mm clearance in the trapped joints, and the looser version with ~.3mm clearance in the trapped joint. A decently calibrated printer should be able to do the normal version without difficulty, but if you end up with a fused joint or don't like how tight the movement is you can always try the looser version instead.

The strength of the hinge will depend on the material it's printed in of course, but printed in PETG I can't make it shift or deform in any dimension in a way that's visible to the naked eye. So it's probably good enough for most non-structural uses.

If not, this part will help you get your cable canal running freely.

An Astartes Fellblade proxy model for Epic scale games (40k or armageddon etc).

Requires superglue to assemble.

very simple pieces, no fancy gubbins, gribble or widgets as my printer is low res. Not particularly pretty but puts a model on the board. With a bit of paint and from 1m away who's going to notice...

This is a relatively large model, possibly a little oversized for epic (photos shown against rhino models by fractalnoise and sicarian by ologhzul) compared to these models it is not hideously large (these things are meant to be as big as a small building) but compared to 'real' epic they're huouge.

from memory most of the bits are original or largely reworked though props to ologhzul for the overall layout (3 piece etc) and sponsons. i had previously printed out some sicarians and scaled things up and simplified surfaces. also inspired by the shadowsword by stroganoff in terms of turret design.

[2017-03-27] revisited the model, fixed a bunch of reverse facings and ran the stls through netfabb. am planning on printing a couple more out so will fix again if required. should be ok.

[2017-03-28] have replaced the 'twin' sponsons with 'quad' versions to make the model WYSIWYG. will be retrofit quads onto my current one, and the two new models will have quads.

[2017-05-02] really minor aesthetic change. the original model i made had a slightly wider body and tracks (left/right). have added these file so they can be used as model options.

p.s. @ whoever is (trying to) sell the old version on ebay for 50 bucks a pop (really, for this blocky lump of a model ?!) at least get the updated quad guns... it's embarrassing.
p.p.s. @ GW i am totally not connected in anyway at all to the person on ebay selling those prints.

I haven't installed electronics yet (missing the servo), so don't ask me for videos of the thing in action just yet...

Cut everything marked with red out of 3mm wood, acrylic or what ever. All the blue items are vector etched, and black is raster engraved. Keep engraved markings pointing inwards and upright (FIXED in this version). The hole in the lid, has to be held in place by a small hinge of some sort (the piece cut out where the servo sits, is glued in place right next to the switch to keep the lid from swinging into the box). I think it's mandatory to mount something funny on the end of the rod switching the box off. I've based the holes and measurements for the servos on Hitec's HS-311 servo, which is rated at [email protected] The microswitch is mounted where i assume the arm will end up once it returns to the off position (still to be tested). Idea, electronics and video of a similar box in action was found here:
http://www.instructables.com/id/The-Most-Useless-Machine/

I was fascinated by the stereographic lamp that henryseg made and thought it would be nice to have a 8x8 field. I did some research and found a plugin for Blender to easily create these objects from a svg file.

I haven't printed it yet, so no warranty that this will come out correctly. Just putting it online in case somebody wants to try.

Doing Stereographic projection objects in Blender

Here's the link to the person who created the plugin ( I guess :)

https://caretdashcaret.com/2014/11/11/stereographic-lampshades-using-the-blender-api/

comments.text:
I really like your idea here. Chess boards are lovely to use but problematical to store.
I downloaded it, but can't get it to slice properly. The best slice gave the the top 4 semicircles & nothing else. I sliced it on several extrusion sizes from 0.2 down to 0.05.
Would love to print this if you fix it!
comments.author: LinneaS

comments.text: Hey there, thanks for the comment. So I hope I fixed every of the bugs now (still can't print it as my printer's broken atm). I think I'll also try to make multiple parts instead of just one big thing to make it easier printing in the end. I'll also add a component to hang the thing somewhere and to fix a lamp (so maybe you'd want to wait for this to happen before giving it a shot :)  cheers
comments.author: LinneaS

title: Lewihe Play hotend fan support (AKA happy boy)

description.text:
This closes my Lewihe Play 3D project. I have completed all the parts I wanted, but I noticed that changing the hotend fan support could be a nightmare if you don't want to disassemble the coreXY system. I had to change and make some proof and I always dropped that damned M4 nuts away... if you understand me... So I thought about a design that could have the nuts embedded so I could assemble the thing without worrying about the nuts. This definitely did its work. Thanks again Lewihe guys for inspiring us, this printer's project has been one of the coolest things I have ever made, This little printer is a wonder in its class. Deeply thanks to you for having this idea Lewihe crew !!! Keep up the good work dudes !!!

This thing accompanies this other design: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1527259

comments.text: Esto para que sirve? Estoy imprimiendo una Play justo ahora, estoy a tiempo de implementar esta pieza.
