title: Fitted Case for Generic Dial Indicator

description.text:
This is a fitted case for a generic Chinese-made 0=1" dial indicator with a 9.5mm (3/8") shank and 60mm dial. These are sold on eBay and Amazon for well under $20, but come packed only in a simple foam "brick" unsuitable for storage in the average toolbox.

This case was designed to offer protection and convenient transportation of this inexpensive but very useful measuring tool.

UPDATE! Added Modified_Fitted_Dial_Indicator_Case.stl to the file list. This one provides accommodation for the Harbor Freight version of this tool, which has a slightly larger loop on its rear face than the "generic" version. (With thanks to blingster for posting the details!)

Printer:

XYZ Da Vinci AiO 1.0

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Good

Infill:

Default

Hinges and latch tab may be relatively fragile in some cases. I found that a liberal "wash" of acetone to these somewhat delicate parts adds considerable strength and durability.

Hinge pin holes may need a bit of cleaning with a small drill bit. Short lengths of 0.025" diameter music wire works well for hinge pins.

The acetone-reinforced latch tab provides a fairly secure "snap" closure. Some tweaking with a small file or sandpaper may make it a bit smoother if desired.

Created a dimensional solid pattern based on actual dimensions of the Dial Indicator, then subtracted that solid from basic box and lid models. Then subtracted other solid bits from the box to minimize filament usage.

All modeling was done using 123D Design software. Sliced and printed with current Da Vinci applications.

title: Lockout Hasp for Breakout EDU
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Remixed two existing models and combined to make a 100% printed hasp for Breakout boxes.

Modifications to hasp:
1) Enlarged lock holes by approximately 1 mm to accommodate larger locks
2) Reduced thickness of each plate to 2.5 mm so overall design is thinner and fits onto toolbox more easily. Could use some more tweaking but definitely works as is. Will update if/when I make more changes.

Modifications to rivet:
1) Enlarged to fit hasp

This hasp was designed thin enough to allow it to fit into the lock hole on my toolbox. However, being thin, one broke during a middle school breakout. I've now uploaded a thicker version of both the hasp and the rivet. May need to redesign more but for now, this modification offers a choice.

  • Lipo Battery (http://www.banggood.com/ZOP-Power-7_4V-650mAh-25C-Lipo-Battery-JST-Plug-p-991741.html)

Code can be found at Github: https://github.com/Bjorn-b/Shottimer_Arduino

Simple slider to indicate the state of a rechargeable battery. I use it on my RC Quadcopter. Simply snap two pieces together and glue it on. Settings: Hi-Res 0.1mm at 25% infill. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/9Ytp6YwufXE

comments.text: Will this print in a 3d printer without additional support material etc? Also is it safe to use an an actual mug?

comments.text: Nylon is the best filament for this, as it is food safe and has a high melting point.
comments.author: mihalisgr

comments.text: actually, not really. You can coat in something or other, may be an epoxy of some kind, then it is safe but nylon/abs/pla are all not safe (and dissolvable and flex filament). search the web for a epoxy if this is a must-print, as I am not an expert

comments.author: mihalisgr

description.text:
A remixed pulley sheave that can be bolted to a structure.

Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1362586
Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=1362586

Pulley case with boltable tabs. Remixing a Customizer parametric model.

Using the parametric feature of Customizer associated with Project: Pulley systems (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1362586), a one pulley unit was remixed. The STL file for the pulley case was downloaded and imported into Rhino 3D where the model's mesh was used as the basis for a pulley case that could be bolted down instead of being hung with line. The Rhino 3D NURB model was then exported as a STL file and loaded into Thingiverse. This model was developed to as an exercise for the Coursera course "The 3D Printing Revolution".
